LINE.WORD: Example-2 Find upper bound for f(n) = n2 + 1
Solution: n2 + 1 2n2, for all n 1
n+1=On)withc=2and n=1
Example-3 Find upper bound for f(n) = n4 + 100n2 + 50
Solution: n4 + 100n2 + 50 2n4, for all n 11
n+100n+50=On)withc=2 and no=11
Example-4 Find upper bound for f(n) = 2n3 - 2n2
Solution:2n3-2n 2n3, for all n > 1
2n3-2n2=On3withc=2 and no=1
Example-5 Find upper bound for f(n) = n
Solution: n n, for all n 1
n =O(n)with c =1 and no=1
Example-6 Find upper bound for f(n) = 410
Solution: 410 410, for all n > 1
410=O(1)withc=1and no=1
No Uniqueness?
There is no unique set of values for no and c in proving the asymptotic bounds. Let us consider.
100n + 5 = O(n). For this function there are multiple no and c values possible..
Solution1:100n+ 5 100n +n=101n 101nfor all n 5,no=5 and c = 101 is a solution.
Solution2:100n + 5 100n + 5n = 105n 105n, for all n > 1,no = 1 and c = 105 is also a
solution.
1.15 Omega-Q Notation [Lower Bounding Function]
Similar to the O discussion, this notation gives the tighter lower bound of the given algorithm and.
we represent it as f(n) = Q(g(n)). That means, at larger values of n, the tighter lower bound of
f(n) is g(n). For example, if f(n) = 100n2 + 10n + 50, g(n) is Q(n2).
